documents.title: Opinion
documents.text:
Case 0:99-cv-03126-DRH     Document 51-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 1 of 21
1 UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS
2 FOR THE SECOND CIRCUIT
3 _______________
4
5 August Term, 2005
6
7 (Argued: June 12, 2006     Decided: August 24, 2006)
8
9 Docket Nos. 05-4206-cv(L); 05-4211-cv(CON); 05-4242-cv(CON)
10 _______________
11
12 IN RE: NASSAU COUNTY STRIP SEARCH CASES
13
14 _______________
15
16 GARDY AUGUSTIN, HEIDI KANE, MARY KATHERINE PUGLIESE, GREGG WILLS, STEVEN ROTH,
17 OSCAR AVELAR, RALPH DILIELLO, JOHN IAFFALDANO, ON BEHALF OF HIMSELF AND OTHERS
18 SIMILARLY SITUATED, FRANCIS O’DAY, AND STUART MOSKOWITZ,
19 Plaintiffs-Appellants,
20 —v.—
21 JOSEPH P. JABLONSKY, SHERIFF OF NASSAU COUNTY, COUNTY OF NASSAU, THOMAS S.
22 GULOTTA, NASSAU COUNTY EXECUTIVE, NASSAU COUNTY SHERIFF’S DEPARTMENT, DIVISION
23 OF CORRECTIONS, PORT WASHINGTON POLICE DISTRICT AND WILLIAM KILFOIL, CHIEF OF
24 POLICE, PORT WASHINGTON POLICE DEPARTMENT, JANE/JOHN DOES 1-200,
25 Defendants-Appellees.
26 _______________
27 B e f o r e :
28 CABRANES, STRAUB, AND HALL, Circuit Judges.
29 _______________
30 Appeal from a series of orders of the United States District Court for the Eastern District
31 of New York (Denis R. Hurley, Judge), denying plaintiffs’ repeated class certification motions
32 for lack of common issue predominance.  The District Court expressed “considerable doubt” as
33 to whether it could certify a class on the issue of liability pursuant to Rule 23(c)(4)(A) when it
34 already had determined that plaintiffs’ claims as a whole failed to satisfy Rule 23(b)(3)’s

Case 0:99-cv-03126-DRH     Document 51-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 2 of 21
1 predominance requirement.  The District Court further concluded that, even if it could do so,
2 common liability issues that defendants had conceded no longer factored into the predominance
3 analysis.  The District Court thus denied plaintiffs’ motion to certify a class on the issue of
4 liability.
5 We hold that (1) district courts may certify a class on a particular issue regardless of
6 whether plaintiffs’ claims, as a whole, satisfy the predominance test; (2) the District Court erred
7 when it excised common liability issues from its predominance analysis due to defendants’
8 concession; and, as a result, (3) the District Court exceeded its allowable discretion in declining
9 to certify a class on the issue of liability pursuant to Rules 23(b)(3) and (c)(4)(A).
10 REVERSED IN PART AND REMANDED IN PART.
11 _________________________________
12 ROBERT L. HERBST, Beldock Levine & Hoffman LLP (Vera M. Scanlon, Spencer B.
13 Freedman, on the brief), New York, NY, for Plaintiffs-Appellants.
14
15 MATTHEW D. BRINCKERHOFF, Emery Celli Brinckerhoff & Abady LLP, New York,
16 NY, for Plaintiffs-Appellants.
17
18 JEFFREY G. SMITH, Wolf Haldenstein Adler Freeman & Herz, LLP, New York, NY,
19 for Plaintiffs-Appellants.
20
21 DENNIS J. SAFFRAN, Deputy County Attorney (Lorna B. Goodman, County Attorney
22 of Nassau County, David B. Goldin, Deputy County Attorney, on the brief), Mineola,
23 NY, for Defendants-Appellees.
24 _________________________________
25 STRAUB, Circuit Judge:
26 This appeal is the latest installment in a series of litigations over the Nassau County
27 Correctional Center’s (“NCCC”) blanket strip search policy for newly admitted, misdemeanor
28 detainees (“the policy”).  Plaintiffs, who were strip searched pursuant to the policy, appeal from a
2

Case 0:99-cv-03126-DRH     Document 51-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 3 of 21
1 series of orders entered in the District Court for the Eastern District of New York (Denis J.
2 Hurley, Judge) denying their repeated motions for class certification on the ground that
3 individual issues predominated over common ones.  See Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b)(3) (requiring that
4 “questions of law or fact common to the members of the class predominate over any questions
5 affecting only individual members”).  
6 During the course of class certification motion practice, plaintiffs requested that the
7 District Court certify a Rule 23(b)(3) class solely on the issue of liability, as permitted by Rule
8 23(c)(4)(A).  In response, defendants conceded their liability to plaintiffs.  The District Court
9 denied the motion.  As an initial matter, the District Court expressed serious doubt over whether
10 it could certify a class on the issue of liability since it already had determined that plaintiffs’
11 claims, as a whole, failed the predominance test.  Even if it could do so, the District Court
12 reasoned that defendants’ concession removed common liability issues from the predominance
13 analysis.  With common liability issues so excised, the Court concluded that individual liability
14 issues, such as the application of an affirmative defense, predominated.  The Court thus denied
15 plaintiffs’ motions for class certification on the issue of liability.
16 The precise issues on appeal are whether (1) a court may certify a Rule 23(b)(3) class as
17 to a particular issue when it already has determined that the claim as a whole fails the
18 predominance test; (2) common issues that are conceded remain part of the predominance
19 analysis; and (3) the District Court exceeded its allowable discretion by failing to certify a class
20 on the issue of liability.  As set forth more fully below, we hold that (1) a court may employ rule
21 23(c)(4)(A) to certify a class as to an issue regardless of whether the claim as a whole satisfies
22 the predominance test; (2) the District Court erred when it concluded that defendants’ concession
3

Case 0:99-cv-03126-DRH     Document 51-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 4 of 21
1 eliminated liability issues from the predominance analysis; and (3) the District Court exceeded its
2 allowable discretion by failing to certify a class on the issue of liability pursuant to Rules
3 23(b)(3) and (c)(4)(A).  Accordingly, we reverse the District Court’s orders dated September 23,
4 2003 and November 7, 2003 to the extent that they deny certification as to the issue of liability,
5 and we remand for proceedings consistent with this opinion.
6 BACKGROUND 
7 In 1999, the District Court for the Eastern District of New York held that defendants’
8 blanket policy of strip searching newly admitted, misdemeanor detainees violated clearly
9 established Fourth Amendment law.  See Shain v. Ellison, 53 F. Supp. 2d 564 (E.D.N.Y. 1999),
10 aff’d,  273 F.3d 56 (2d Cir. 2001).  Although the policy has never been formally enjoined, Shain
11 v. Ellison, 356 F.3d 211 (2d Cir. 2004) (vacating injunction for lack of standing), defendants
12 assert that following the District Court’s 1999 decision, they ceased implementing it.
13 Shortly after the District Court’s 1999 decision, plaintiffs brought three separate actions
14 in the Eastern District of New York: Augustin v. Jablonsky, No. 99 Civ. 3126, O’Day et al. v.
15 Nassau County Sheriff’s Department, et al., No. 99 Civ. 2844, and Iaffaldano v. County of
16 Nassau, No. 99 Civ. 4238.  Together, plaintiffs named as defendants Nassau County, Sheriff
17 Joseph P. Jablonsky, the Sheriff’s Department, County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta, the
18 Division of Corrections, the Port Washington Police District and its chief of police, William
19 Kilfoil, and up to 200 subordinate John and Jane Doe corrections officers.
20 Each action alleged that plaintiffs were arrested on misdemeanor charges unrelated to
21 weapons or drugs and thereafter strip searched, without individualized suspicion, pursuant to the
22 policy.  Plaintiffs claimed that the strip searches violated 42 U.S.C. § 1983, the Fourth, Fifth,
4

Case 0:99-cv-03126-DRH     Document 51-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 5 of 21
1 Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution, and Article 1, section 12
2 of the New York State Constitution.  They sought compensatory and punitive damages, a
3 declaration that the policy was unconstitutional, and an injunction barring enforcement of the
4 policy.  They also sought to maintain each litigation as a class action.
5 In February of 2000, plaintiffs moved to consolidate all three actions and certify a unified
6 class pursuant to Rule 23(b)(3).1  Plaintiffs defined the class as follows: “[A]ll persons arrested
7 for or charged with non-felony offenses who have been admitted to the Nassau County
8 Correctional Center and strip searched without particularized reasonable suspicion.”  In an
9 opinion and order dated March 8, 2001, the District Court granted that branch of the motion
10 seeking consolidation and denied that branch seeking class certification.  See Augustin v.
11 Jabolonsky, No. 99 Civ. 3126, 2001 WL 770839 (E.D.N.Y. Mar. 8, 2001). 
12 The District Court determined that plaintiffs satisfied the four requirements of
13 numerosity, commonality, typicality, and adequacy of representation.  See Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a). 
14 However, it denied certification for lack of common issue predominance.  The Court recognized
15 certain common questions, namely, (1) whether defendants maintained a blanket strip search
16 policy; (2) whether that policy was unconstitutional; and (3) whether some or all defendants may
17 be held liable.  Nonetheless, it determined that individualized issues predominated, in particular:
18 (1) whether subordinate Jane and John Doe defendants might escape liability in some cases
19 because, notwithstanding the blanket policy, they had reasonable suspicion to search certain
20 detainees; (2) the existence of proximate causation for each alleged injury; and (3) compensatory
1Because motion practice on the question of class certification continued in various
iterations for more than four years, we describe only those aspects of the District Court’s
decisions that are relevant to our own.
5

Case 0:99-cv-03126-DRH     Document 51-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 6 of 21
1 and punitive damages calculations.
2 The District Court noted the possibility of sua sponte certifying a class solely on the issue
3 of liability pursuant to Rule 23(c)(4)(A), which allows for class certification “with respect to
4 particular issues.”  It declined to do so because it did not wish to “undertake plaintiffs’ burden”
5 to “craft and submit a proposal,” and because, as a legal matter, it perceived “considerable doubt
6 as to the propriety of using Rule 23(c)(4)(A) in this fashion.”  In particular, the Court relied on
7 Castano v. Am. Tobacco Co., 84 F.3d 734 (5th Cir. 1996) for the proposition that courts may not
8 employ Rule 23(c)(4)(A) to single out the issue of liability for class treatment unless the “cause
9 of action, as a whole,” first satisfies Rule 23(b)(3)’s predominance requirement.  Id. at 745 n.21
10 (emphasis added by District Court).
11 Plaintiffs moved for reconsideration.  They first asserted that they would no longer seek
12 judgment against subordinate Jane and John Doe defendants.  Since that modification would
13 render the question of liability identical for nearly all class members, plaintiffs next asserted that
14 the Court should certify a class on the issue of liability pursuant to Rule 23(c)(4)(A).  They again
15 defined the class as “all persons arrested for or charged with non-felony offenses who have been
16 admitted to the [Nassau County Correctional Center] and strip searched without particularized
17 reasonable suspicion.”
18 In an opinion and order dated May 23, 2001, the Court agreed that plaintiffs’ forbearance
19 of their claims against subordinate defendants “removes the possibility of individualized liability
20 determinations.”  “To be sure,” the Court acknowledged, “the absence of individualized
21 questions of liability militates in favor of partial certification solely on that issue.”  It
22 nevertheless denied the motion.  
6

Case 0:99-cv-03126-DRH     Document 51-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 7 of 21
1 The District Court again noted its “concern that partial certification might not be
2 appropriate in the first instance where the cause of action, as a whole, does not satisfy the
3 predominance requirement of Rule 23(b)(3).”  “Even assuming” that Rule 23(c)(4)(A) could be
4 used in that fashion, the Court denied the motion because plaintiffs’ proposed class definition
5 “would necessitate mini-trials just to determine class membership.”  In order to determine class
6 membership, the Court believed, each would-be class member would have to show affirmatively
7 that he was strip searched without particularized reasonable suspicion – a criterion that the
8 definition incorporated.  This burden was complicated by the fact that defendants claimed that
9 they had ceased the blanket strip search policy after the Eastern District’s 1999 decision in Shain,
10 and thereafter conducted strip searches only with particularized reasonable suspicion.
11 In January 2003, plaintiffs renewed their motion for class certification as to liability and
12 offered a new definition of the class as follows: “[A]ll persons arrested for misdemeanors or non-
13 criminal offenses in Nassau County who thereafter were strip-searched at the NCCC pursuant to
14 defendants’ blanket policy, practice and custom which required that all arrestees be strip-
15 searched upon admission to the facility . . . .”  (alterations incorporated).  By referring only to the
16 “blanket policy,” this new definition did not require plaintiffs to show that reasonable suspicion
17 was absent in each case, and it excluded individuals strip searched after the 1999 Shain decision,
18 when defendants ceased implementing the policy.  Plaintiffs also reiterated that they withdrew
19 their claims against individual John and Jane Doe corrections officers.
20 In response, defendants conceded “the one common issue” that in their view “might be
21 appropriate for class certification . . . namely, whether the NCCC’s strip search policy during the
22 class period was constitutional.”  (alterations incorporated).  Specifically, defendants recognized
7

Case 0:99-cv-03126-DRH     Document 51-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 8 of 21
1 that they “are bound by Shain under the doctrine of collateral estoppel.”  
2 The District Court denied the renewed motion.  In an opinion and order dated September
3 23, 2003, the Court determined that defendants’ concession removed all common liability issues
4 from its predominance analysis.  Accordingly, the only liability issue that remained was an
5 individual one: whether, notwithstanding the policy, some plaintiffs were searched based upon
6 “reasonable and contemporaneously held suspicion.”  “With the liability issue thus
7 circumscribed,” the Court wrote, “certification as to that issue would not serve any purpose.” 
8 Interestingly, the Court recognized that the individualized “‘reasonable suspicion inquiries’ will
9 be de minimis” for two reasons: because defendants conceded that “such an inquiry will only be
10 sought regarding a limited number of plaintiffs,” and because pursuant to United States v. Colon,
11 250 F.3d 130, 138 (2d Cir. 2001), reasonable suspicion must be possessed by some law
12 enforcement officer at the time of the search and may not be retroactively imputed.
13 Plaintiffs moved again for reconsideration on October 2, 2003.  In an opinion and order
14 dated November 7, 2003, the District Court adhered to its earlier determinations and also
15 concluded – for the first time – that for the same reasons informing its predominance analysis,
16 plaintiffs failed to satisfy another one of Rule 23(b)(3)’s requirements, specifically, that the
17 proposed class action be “superior to other available methods for the fair and efficient
18 adjudication of the controversy.”  Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b)(3).  In one last effort to “determine if its
19 decision was in some other way improper,” the Court examined the policies of efficiency and
20 uniformity animating Rule 23, and concluded that they did not favor certification.  The Court
21 also noted that individual plaintiffs would have little trouble securing counsel to pursue their
22 claims because their damages likely would be large enough to provide the necessary economic
8

Case 0:99-cv-03126-DRH     Document 51-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 9 of 21
1 incentive.
2 The parties later reached a settlement in which defendants paid the lump sum of $350,000
3 to the ten plaintiffs, who agreed to split the funds equally.  Plaintiffs reserved their right to appeal
4 the District Court’s orders denying class certification, which they timely exercised.2 
5 DISCUSSION
6 I. Standard of Review
7  We review the District Court’s denial of class certification for abuse of discretion. 
8 Robinson v. Metro-North Commuter R.R. Co., 267 F.3d 147, 162 (2d Cir. 2001).  However, we
9 “review de novo the district court’s conclusions of law that informed its decision to deny class
10 certification.”  Parker v. Time Warner Entm’t Co., 331 F.3d 13, 18 (2d Cir. 2003) (quotation
11 marks omitted).  Further, we are “noticeably less deferential when the district court has denied
12 class status than when it has certified a class.”  Id. (quotation marks omitted and alterations
13 incorporated); Robinson, 267 F.3d at 162.  We note that while the application of the incorrect
14 legal principle often necessitates reversal under the “abuse of discretion” standard, such reversal
15 need not indicate any “abuse” by the District Court as that word is commonly understood.  See
16 Zervos v. Verizon N.Y., Inc., 252 F.3d 163, 168-69 & nn.4-6 (2d Cir. 2001) (distinguishing
17 among various meanings of “abuse of discretion”).  
18 II. The Requirements and Purpose of Rule 23(b)(3)
19
20 In order to achieve class certification pursuant to Rule 23(b)(3), plaintiffs must (1) satisfy
21 the four requirements of Rule 23(a), which are numerosity, typicality, commonality, and
2Although these plaintiffs have settled their individual claims, they have reserved their
right, in the event of a class settlement, to “seek or receive additional compensation for attorney’s
fees and [their] time and effort as . . . class representative[s].”
9

Case 0:99-cv-03126-DRH     Document 51-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 10 of 21
1 adequacy of representation; (2) demonstrate that common “questions of law or fact” predominate
2 over “any questions affecting only individual members”; and (3) establish that the class action
3 mechanism is “superior to other available methods for the fair and efficient adjudication of the
4 controversy.”  Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b)(3).
5 As a general matter, the “Rule 23(b)(3) predominance inquiry tests whether proposed
6 classes are sufficiently cohesive to warrant adjudication by representation.”  In re Visa
7 Check/MasterMoney Antitrust Litig., 280 F.3d 124, 136 (2d Cir. 2001) (quotation marks
8 omitted).  The Rule “encompasses those cases in which a class action would achieve economies
9 of time, effort, and expense, and promote uniformity of decision as to persons similarly situated,
10 without sacrificing procedural fairness or bringing about other undesirable results.”  Fed. R. Civ.
11 P. 23(b)(3) adv. comm. n. to 1966 amend.
12 In light of these purposes, we have set forth that although “a defense may arise and may
13 affect different class members differently, [this occurrence] does not compel a finding that
14 individual issues predominate over common ones.”  In re Visa Check, 280 F.3d at 138 (internal
15 quotation marks omitted).  So “long as a sufficient constellation of common issues binds class
16 members together, variations in the sources and application of a defense will not automatically
17 foreclose class certification.”  Id. (quotation marks omitted and alterations incorporated).
18 III. The District Court Erred in Failing to Certify a Class on the Issue of Liability
19 Pursuant to Rules 23(b)(3) and (c)(4)(A)
20 As set forth more fully below, we conclude that the District Court erred by failing to
21 certify a class on the issue of liability.3  We first conclude that, contrary to the District Court’s
3We reach this conclusion without considering whether the District Court should have
certified a class as to plaintiffs’ entire claims – an issue that, as set forth more fully below, we
10

Case 0:99-cv-03126-DRH     Document 51-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 11 of 21
1 reservations, a court may employ Rule 23(c)(4)(A) to certify a class on a particular issue even if
2 the action as a whole does not satisfy Rule 23(b)(3)’s predominance requirement.  Second, we
3 hold that the District Court committed legal error in concluding that defendants’ concession
4 eliminated common liability issues from Rule 23(b)(3)’s predominance analysis.  Third, this
5 error caused the District Court to exceed its allowable discretion in concluding that
6 individualized liability issues predominated over common ones, and that the class action
7 mechanism is not a superior litigation vehicle under these circumstances.
8 A. A District Court May Certify a Class as to Specific Issues Regardless of
9 Whether the Entire Claim Satisfies Rule 23(b)(3)
10
11 Whether a court may employ Rule 23(c)(4)(A) to certify a class as to a specific issue
12 where the entire claim does not satisfy Rule 23(b)(3)’s predominance requirement is a matter of
13 first impression in this Circuit.  See Robinson, 267 F.3d at 167 n.12 (identifying question as one
14 of first impression and declining to resolve it).  It also is a matter as to which the Circuits have
15 split.  Id.  
16 The Fifth Circuit has adopted a “strict application” of Rule 23(b)(3)’s predominance
17 requirement.  Id.  Under this view, “[t]he proper interpretation of the interaction between
18 subdivisions (b)(3) and (c)(4) is that a cause of action, as a whole, must satisfy the predominance
19 requirement of (b)(3) and that (c)(4) is a housekeeping rule that allows courts to sever the
20 common issues for a class trial.”  Castano v. Am. Tobacco Co., 84 F.3d 734, 745 n.21 (5th Cir.
21 1996).
22 The Ninth Circuit holds a different view.  Pursuant to that court’s precedent, “[e]ven if
ask the District Court to revisit in light of our holdings.
11

Case 0:99-cv-03126-DRH     Document 51-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 12 of 21
1 the common questions do not predominate over the individual questions so that class certification
2 of the entire action is warranted, Rule 23 authorizes the district court in appropriate cases to
3 isolate the common issues under Rule 23(c)(4)(A) and proceed with class treatment of these
4 particular issues.”  Valentino v. Carter-Wallace, Inc., 97 F.3d 1227, 1234 (9th Cir. 1996);  cf.
5 Gunnells v. Healthplan Servs., Inc., 348 F.3d 417, 439 (4th Cir. 2003) (holding that courts may
6 employ Rule 23(c) to certify a class as to one claim even though all of plaintiffs’ claims, taken
7 together, do not satisfy the predominance requirement).  
8 We agree with the Ninth Circuit’s view of the matter.  First, the plain language and
9 structure of Rule 23 support the Ninth Circuit’s view.  Rule 23(c)(4) provides as follows:
10 When appropriate (A) an action may be brought or maintained as a
11 class action with respect to particular issues, or (B) a class may be
12 divided into subclasses and each subclass treated as a class, and the
13 provisions of this rule shall then be construed and applied
14 accordingly.    
15 Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(c)(4) (emphases added).
16 As the rule’s plain language and structure establish, a court must first identify the issues
17 potentially appropriate for certification “and . . . then” apply the other provisions of the rule, i.e.,
18 subsection (b)(3) and its predominance analysis.  See Gunnells, 348 F.3d at 439 (reasoning that
19 the rule’s language provides this “express command” that “courts have no discretion to ignore”).
20 Second, the Advisory Committee Notes confirm this understanding.  With respect to
21 subsection (c)(4), the notes set forth that, “[f]or example, in a fraud or similar case the action
22 may retain its ‘class’ character only through the adjudication of liability to the class; the members
23 of the class may thereafter be required to come in individually and prove the amounts of their
24 respective claims.”  Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(c)(4) adv. comm. n. to 1966 amend. (emphasis added). 
12

Case 0:99-cv-03126-DRH     Document 51-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 13 of 21
1 As the notes point out, a court may employ Rule 23(c)(4) when it is the “only” way that a
2 litigation retains its class character, i.e., when common questions predominate only as to the
3 “particular issues” of which the provision speaks.  Further, the notes illustrate that a court may
4 properly employ this technique to separate the issue of liability from damages.
5 In addition, as the Fourth Circuit has noted, the Fifth Circuit’s view renders subsection
6 (c)(4) virtually null, which contravenes the “well-settled” principle “that courts should avoid
7 statutory interpretations that render provisions superfluous.”  State St. Bank & Trust Co. v.
8 Salovaara, 326 F.3d 130, 139 (2d Cir. 2003).  Pursuant to the Fifth Circuit’s view, “a court
9 considering the manageability of a class action – a requirement for predominance under Rule
10 23(b)(3)(D) – [would have] to pretend that subsection (c)(4) – a provision specifically included
11 to make a class action more manageable – does not exist until after the manageability
12 determination [has been] made.”  Gunnells, 348 F.3d at 439.  Accordingly, “a court could only
13 use subsection (c)(4) to manage cases that the court had already determined would be
14 manageable without consideration of subsection (c)(4).”  Id.
15 Finally, we note that the commentators agree that courts may use subsection (c)(4) to
16 single out issues for class treatment when the action as a whole does not satisfy Rule 23(b)(3). 
17 See 7AA Wright & Miller, Federal Practice & Procedure § 1790 (3d ed. 2005) (stating that
18 subsection (c)(4) “best may be used to designate appropriate classes or class issues at the
19 certification stage” so that “the court can determine whether, as so designated, the other Rule 23
20 requirements are satisfied”); 6 Alba Conte & Herbert B. Newberg, Newberg on Class Actions §
21 18:7 (4th ed. 2002) (“Even cases which might not satisfy the predominance test when the case is
22 viewed as a whole may sometimes be certified as a class limited to selected issues that are
13

Case 0:99-cv-03126-DRH     Document 51-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 14 of 21
1 common, under the authority of Rule 23(c)(4).”).
2 For those reasons, we hold that a court may employ subsection (c)(4) to certify a class as
3 to liability regardless of whether the claim as a whole satisfies Rule 23(b)(3)’s predominance
4 requirement.
5 B. The District Court Erred When It Concluded that Defendants’ Concession
6 Eliminates Common Liability Issues from Rule 23(b)(3)’s Predominance
7 Analysis
8
9 As noted above, the District Court reasoned that the major liability issues common to the
10 class – whether defendants implemented a blanket strip search policy, and if so, whether they are
11 liable for it – were eliminated from the predominance analysis by defendants’ concession. 
12 Whether a concession can limit the predominance analysis in that fashion also is a question of
13 first impression.  For three reasons, we conclude that a concession does not eliminate a common
14 issue from the predominance calculus, and that the District Court erred in holding otherwise.
15 First, because the predominance analysis tests whether the class is a “‘sufficiently
16 cohesive’” unit, In re Visa Check, 280 F.3d at 136, all factual or legal issues that are common to
17 the class inform the analysis.  See Amchem Prods., Inc. v. Windsor, 521 U.S. 591, 621 (1997)
18 (“Subdivisions (a) and (b) focus court attention on whether a proposed class has sufficient unity
19 so that absent members can fairly be bound by decisions of class representatives.”).   In turn, an
20 issue is common to the class when it is susceptible to generalized, class-wide proof.  In re Visa
21 Check, 280 F.3d at 136 (“In order to meet the predominance requirement . . . a plaintiff must
22 establish that the issues in the class action that are subject to generalized proof, and thus
23 applicable to the class as a whole, predominate over those issues that are subject only to
14

Case 0:99-cv-03126-DRH     Document 51-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 15 of 21
1 individualized proof.” (internal quotation marks omitted and alteration incorporated)); see also
2 Heerwagen v. Clear Channel Commc’ns, 435 F.3d 219, 226 (2d Cir. 2006) (noting that “a
3 plaintiff must show that those issues . . . subject to generalized proof outweigh those issues that
4 are subject to individualized proof”); Moore v. PaineWebber, Inc., 306 F.3d 1247, 1252 (2d Cir.
5 2002) (same).  That the class-wide proof comes in the form of a simple concession rather than
6 contested evidence certainly shortens the time that the court must spend adjudicating the issue,
7 but it does nothing to alter the fundamental cohesion of the proposed class, which is the central
8 concern of the predominance requirement.  See 2 Alba Conte & Herbert B. Newberg, Newberg
9 on Class Actions § 4:25 (4th ed. 2002) (“[T]he predominance test does not involve a comparison
10 of court time needed to adjudicate common issues weighed against time needed to dispose of
11 individual issues . . . .”); 7AA Wright & Miller, Federal Practice and Procedure § 1778 (3d ed.
12 2005) (“[C]lockwatching is not very helpful in ascertaining whether class-action treatment would
13 be desirable in a particular case.”).  Similarly, the fact that an issue is conceded or otherwise
14 resolved does not mean that it ceases to be an “issue” for the purposes of predominance analysis. 
15 Even resolved questions continue to implicate the “common nucleus of operative facts and
16 issues” with which the predominance inquiry is concerned.  See Waste Mgmt. Holdings, Inc. v.
17 Mowbray, 208 F.3d 288, 299 (1st Cir. 2000) (“[T]he fact that an issue has been resolved on
18 summary judgment does not remove it from the predominance calculus.”).  Just as much as do
19 contested issues, resolved issues bear on the key question that the analysis seeks to answer:
20 whether the class is a legally coherent unit of representation by which absent class members may
21 fairly be bound. 
22 Second, Rule 23 seeks greater efficiency via collective adjudication and, relatedly, greater
15

Case 0:99-cv-03126-DRH     Document 51-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 16 of 21
1 uniformity of decision as to similarly situated parties.  See Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b)(3) adv. comm. n.
2 to 1966 amend.  For these reasons we have written that when plaintiffs are “allegedly aggrieved
3 by a single policy of defendants,” such as the blanket policy at issue here, the case presents
4 “precisely the type of situation for which the class action device is suited” since many nearly
5 identical litigations can be adjudicated in unison.  In re Visa Check, 280 F.3d at 146.  
6 Eliminating conceded issues from Rule 23(b)(3)’s predominance calculus would
7 undermine the goal of efficiency by requiring plaintiffs who share a “commonality of the
8 violation and the harm,” nonetheless to pursue separate and potentially numerous actions
9 because, ironically, liability is so clear.  Id. (noting that class action management “problems pale
10 in comparison to the burden on the courts that would result from trying the cases individually”). 
11 Such a result also undermines the goal of uniformity by creating the risk of inconsistent decisions
12 through the repeated litigation of the same question; here, for example, each individual plaintiff
13 would have to establish anew that defendants were collaterally estopped by their prior concession
14 and, if not, that defendants were liable on the merits.  Cf. Waste Mgmt. Holdings, Inc., 208 F.3d
15 at 299 (concluding that because certification was “necessary to determine whether the prior
16 resolution carries res judicata effect with respect to purported class members,” the district court
17 properly took account of “the common nucleus of operative facts and issues, even though certain
18 of these already had been resolved”).  Although defendants have conceded liability to these
19 plaintiffs, there is no guarantee that they would concede liability in a case or series of cases
20 involving significantly higher damages.  Further, courts might differ as to whether, in light of the
21 settlement, the requirements of collateral estoppel were met, specifically, whether the issue of
22 liability was “actually litigated and decided” and whether its “resolution  . . . was necessary to
16

Case 0:99-cv-03126-DRH     Document 51-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 17 of 21
1 support a valid and final judgment on the merits.”  Ball v. A.O. Smith Corp., 451 F.3d 66, 69 (2d
2 Cir. 2006); cf. In re Tamoxifen Citrate Antitrust Litig., 429 F.3d 370, 387 n.15 (2d Cir. 2005)
3 (“[I]t is clearly a permissible byproduct of settlement that future hypothetical plaintiffs might be
4 forced to relitigate the same issues involved in the settled cases.”); Marvel Characters, Inc. v.
5 Simon, 310 F.3d 280, 289 (2d Cir. 2002).
6 Finally, we find further support for our view in the specific circumstances of this case. 
7 Defendants possess, but have not disclosed, records of all the newly-admitted misdemeanor
8 detainees strip searched pursuant to the blanket policy.  Absent class certification and its
9 attendant class-wide notice procedures, most of these individuals – who potentially number in the
10 thousands – likely never will know that defendants violated their clearly established
11 constitutional rights, and thus never will be able to vindicate those rights.  As a practical matter,
12 then, without use of the class action mechanism, individuals harmed by defendants’ policy and
13 practice may lack an effective remedy altogether.  Cf. Deposit Guar. Nat. Bank v. Roper, 445
14 U.S. 326, 339 (1980) (noting that in certain cases “aggrieved persons may be without any
15 effective redress unless they may employ the class-action device”); Tardiff v. Knox County, 365
16 F.3d 1, 7 (1st Cir. 2004) (“[F]or most strip search claimants, class status here is not only the
17 superior means, but probably the only feasible one (one-way collateral estoppel aside), to
18 establish liability and perhaps damages.”).  Further, if defendants may utilize their concession to
19 defeat class certification, it would work the perverse result of allowing them to escape the cost of
20 their unconstitutional behavior precisely because their liability is too plain to be denied.  No
21 other court has sanctioned such a result; nor shall we.
22 Accordingly, we hold that defendants’ concession of liability does not eliminate that
17

Case 0:99-cv-03126-DRH     Document 51-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 18 of 21
1 otherwise common issue from Rule 23(b)(3)’s predominance analysis, and the District Court
2 erred when it concluded to the contrary.
3 C. The District Court Erred in Determining that, as to Liability, Individual Issues
4 Predominated
5
6 As we have established, the District Court was (1) free to certify a class on the issue of
7 liability notwithstanding its conclusion that the action as a whole did not satisfy the
8 predominance requirement and (2) required to consider conceded common liability issues in its
9 predominance analysis.  We now apply these principles to the District Court’s opinion and order
10 dated September 23, 2003 in which it denied certification on the issue of liability, as well as that
11 dated November 7, 2003 in which it adhered to its September decision.  The class definition at
12 issue was as follows: “[A]ll persons arrested for misdemeanors or non-criminal offenses in
13 Nassau County who thereafter were strip-searched at the NCCC pursuant to defendants’ blanket
14 policy, practice and custom which required that all arrestees be strip-searched upon admission to
15 the facility . . . .”  (alterations incorporated).  
16 As noted, that definition obviated the need for individualized proceedings to determine
17 class membership.  The definition referenced only defendants’ “blanket policy,” thus avoiding
18 questions of probable cause and excluding individuals strip searched after the policy’s cessation.
19 Since defendants possess records of misdemeanor detainees strip searched during the policy
20 period, determining class membership would be simple.  In re Visa Check, 280 F.3d at 142
21 (approving class certification where “class members . . . can be identified by defendants’ own
22 records”).
23 The class definition also implicated two broad common liability issues: whether the
18

Case 0:99-cv-03126-DRH     Document 51-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 19 of 21
1 blanket policy existed and whether defendants are liable for its implementation.  The only
2 countervailing, individualized liability issue was whether, regardless of the policy, some
3 plaintiffs were strip searched based upon “reasonable and contemporaneously held suspicion.” 
4 The existence of this defense does “not . . . foreclose class certification.”  Id. at 138 (internal
5 quotation marks omitted).  Further, as the District Court recognized, “any such ‘reasonable
6 suspicion inquiries’ will be de minimis”; indeed, defendants set forth that “such an inquiry will
7 only be sought regarding a limited number of plaintiffs.”  In light of the pervasive character of
8 the common liability issues and the admittedly de minimis nature of individualized liability
9 issues, we conclude that the District Court erred by holding that individual liability issues
10 predominated over common ones in its decisions dated September 23, 2003, and November 7,
11 2003.
12 D. The District Court Erred in Concluding that the Class Action Device Is Not a
13 Superior Litigation Mechanism
14
15 For Rule 23(b)(3) certification to be proper, a class action also must be the most “fair and
16 efficient” method of resolving this case.  See Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b)(3).  In analyzing that question,
17 courts must consider four nonexclusive factors: (1) the interest of the class members in
18 maintaining separate actions; (2) “the extent and nature of any litigation concerning the
19 controversy already commenced by or against members of the class”; (3) “the desirability or
20 undesirability of concentrating the litigation of the claims in the particular forum”; and (4) “the
21 difficulties likely to be encountered in the management of a class action.”  See Fed. R. Civ. P.
22 23(b)(3).  Contrary to the District Court’s conclusion in its decision dated November 7, 2003, all
23 of these factors – as well as the reasons set forth above regarding efficiency and fairness – favor
19

Case 0:99-cv-03126-DRH     Document 51-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 20 of 21
1 class certification.
2 First, the class members have little interest in maintaining separate actions since there
3 already exists a concession of liability in this action and, without class notification, most putative
4 class members will not even know that they suffered a violation of their constitutional rights. 
5 Second, this action already has progressed substantially and, again, offers the benefit of a liability
6 phase that can be resolved quickly and conclusively.  Third, concentrating the litigation in one
7 forum simplifies and streamlines the litigation process.  Fourth, we perceive little difficulty in
8 managing a class action on the issue of liability, especially since the District Court already has
9 noted that any individualized inquiries will be few and far between.  Accordingly, we conclude
10 that the District Court erred in holding that a class action was not the most fair and efficient
11 litigation vehicle under these circumstances.
12 CONCLUSION
13 We hold that (1) district courts may employ Rule 23(c)(4)(A) to certify a class on a
14 designated issue regardless of whether the claim as a whole satisfies the predominance test; (2)
15 conceded common issues remain part of the predominance analysis; and (3) the District Court
16 exceeded its allowable discretion in denying Rule 23(b)(3) and (c)(4)(A) class certification on the
17 issue of liability in its decisions dated September 23, 2003 and November 7, 2003.4
4Because we have found that certification as to liability is proper pursuant to Rule
23(b)(3), there is “no necessity” of addressing alternate grounds for certification, such as Rule
23(b)(2), that the District Court rejected.  Cf. In re Visa Check, 280 F.3d at 147 (declining to
review district court’s ruling on Rule 23(b)(2) certification after concluding that Rule 23(b)(3)
certification was proper) (internal quotation marks omitted).  Further, since we base our decision
on the September 23, 2003 and November 7, 2003 orders, we need not consider the District
Court’s August 20, 2004 order, in which it rejected a radically different class definition for
failure to satisfy Rule 23(a).  
20

Case 0:99-cv-03126-DRH     Document 51-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 21 of 21
1 In light of our direction to certify a class on the issue of liability pursuant to the definition
2 set forth in the September 23 decision, we also instruct the District Court to consider anew
3 whether to certify a class as to damages as well.  The District Court should bear in mind that
4 “[t]here are a number of management tools available to a district court to address any
5 individualized damages issues,” such as bifurcation, the use of a magistrate or special master,
6 alteration of the class definition, the creation of subclasses, or even decertification after a finding
7 of liability.  In re Visa Check, 280 F.3d at 141.  
8 In sum, we remand to the District Court with instructions to certify a class as to liability
9 and consider certifying a damages class as well.
21

04/10/2014 465  FINAL JUDGMENT; That the Clerk of Court is directed to enter final judgment as
follows: FINAL JUDGMENT IS HEREBY ENTERED for defendants and against
plaintiffs and the class on the federal constitutional claims. FINAL JUDGMENT IS
HEREBY ENTERED for plaintiffs and the class and against defendants County of
Nassau and Joseph Jablonsky, jointly and severally, on the state constitutional claim in
the aggregate sum of $11,508,000, with post judgment interest from the entry of
judgment at the rate prescribed in 28 U.S.C. § 1961 (a). To effectuate this recovery,
defendants are ORDERED to deposit into Court the sum of $11,508,000 within 30
days of entry of final judgment. Members of the certified liability and damages class
shall recover from that Common Fund in the amountof $500 per strip search upon
admission during the class period, pursuant to the Notice and Claims Process described
below. Within 60 days of entry of final judgment, the Administrator shall mail the
Notice annexed hereto as Exhibit 1to the 1,963 class members whom the County
contends may have been booked at the NCCC and released on bail before being strip
searched on admission, together with the Claim Form that is annexed hereto as Exhibit
2. At the same time, the Administrator shall mail the Notice annexed hereto as Exhibit
3 to the rest ofthe class members, together with the Claim Form that is annexed hereto
as Exhibit 4. Claim forms mailed in by class members shall be postmarked no later
than December 15, 2015. As set forth in both Notices, the statute of limitations for
class members' filing of individual lawsuits for special damages is ORDERED tolled
for an additional period of 180 days after entryof final judgment. If an appeal is taken
from final judgment, the 180−day additional tolling period will not begin to run until
the issuance of the mandate from the Court of Appeals. All costs of administration
having previously been imposed upon defendants as a result of their concession and
resulting judgment of liability, those costs shall continue to be paid by defendants.
Invoices rendered by the Administrator to defendants shall bepaid within 30 days of
receipt thereof. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that the County will furnish to plaintiffs'
counsel the required "Booking #[s]" and "Date[s] ofArrest" for insertion into the
"Claim Form[s]" (Exhibits 2 & 4) within 30 days of entry of final judgment. IT IS
FURTHER ORDERED that, in accordance with theMemorandum and Order dated

04/30/2014 471  MEMORANDUM AND ORDER, defendants' application for an extension of the time
in which to make the necessary deposit under the April 10, 2014 judgment is denied as
premature. As to the claim that the amount of the deposit is excessive as far exceeding
the dollar amount of anticipated claims to be made against the common fund, that
application is denied because (1) it was not advanced previously, and (2) it is
unaccompanied by statutory or decisional authority indicating that the requested
adjustment should be made. Lastly, the defendants correctly not that the judgment as
written requires that deposit of the money absent any provision about interest being
earned on those monies during a period they are held by the Court Clerk. Accordingly,
as part of the anticipated stay application, I will entertain an application that I direct
the Clerk to place the deposited common fund in an interest bearing account and I will
welcome input from counsel as to the nature of the account into which the sums should
be deposited. terminating 468 Motion to Alter Judgment. Ordered by Judge Denis R.
Hurley on 4/30/2014. (Lundy, Lisa) (Entered: 04/30/2014)

plaintiffs' filing and the reply, if any, being due on or before 10 business days
thereafter; and it is further ORDERED that the agreed upon changes to the claim form
set forth in plaintiff's letter of July 8, 2016 are approved and that the claim form shall
state, with respect to the time limits for filing a lawsuit for damages beyond the $500
per strip search, as follows:The time limits for filing a lawsuit for additional damages
are based on the three−year statute of limitations applicable to these claims. The Court
placed a hold (i.e. stoppage on the running of the three year statute of limitations) on
May 20, 1999. That hold continues to be in effect until 180 days after June 16, 2016,
so that you will have until at least December 13, 2016 to file an individual lawsuit for
additional damages. This means the amount of time you have to file a separate lawsuit
depends upon the date you were stripped search. For example, if you were strip
searched anytime from May 20, 1996 until November 16, 1996, you have until
December 13, 2016 to file a separate individual lawsuit for additional damages. For
example, if you were strip searched on June 1, 1997, you would have one year after
December 13, 2016 to file your individual lawsuit for additional damages. If you were
strip searched on June 1, 1998, you would have two years after December 13, 2016 to
file your individual lawsuit for additional damages. If you were strip searched on June
1, 1999, you have the entire three−year statute of limitations period to file a separate
lawsuit. If you have a question about additional damages or the amount of time you
have to file a separate you should contact an attorney. See attached Memorandum &
Order. Ordered by Judge Denis R. Hurley on 7/28/2016. (Gapinski, Michele) (Entered:
07/28/2016)

Parties on or about May 17, 2005 and "So Ordered" by this Court oS2 0~, final 
judgment will be entered in favor of the ten individual plaintiffs in the three consolidated cases 
against defendants County of Nassau and Joseph Jablonsky, jointly and severally, in the 
aggregate amount of $350,000 in compensatory damages for personal injury.  Plaintiffs have 
requested that the $350,000 in damages be distributed evenly among the ten individual plaintiffs. 
Defendants have no objection to this distribution.  The parties agree that the $35,000 in 
compensatory damages received by each individual plaintiff in no way reflects a concession by 
defendants that the amount received is the actual value of any such claim made now or in the 
future. 
The Clerk is hereby directed to enter final judgment for each of the individual plaintiffs 
against defendants County of Nassau and Joseph Jablonsky, jointly and severally, as follows: 
Francis O'Day - $35,000; Stuart Moskowitz - $35,000; Gardy Augustin -$35,000; Heidi Kane-

-$35,000; Ralph DiLiello - $35,000; and John Iaffaldano - $35,000.

documents.title: Memorandum and Order
documents.text:
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT
EASTERN DISTRICT OF NEW YORK
- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - X
In re NASSAU COUNTY 99-CV-3126 (DRH)
STRIP SEARCH CASES 99-CV-2844 (DRH)
99-CV-4238 (DRH)
- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - X         MEMORANDUM  AND ORDER
A P P E A R A N C E S:
For the Plaintiffs:
Beldock Levine & Hoffman LLP
99 Park Avenue, Suite 1600
New York, New York 10016
By: Robert L. Herbst, Esq.
Jonathan C. Moore, Esq.
Vera M. Scanlon, Esq.
Emery Celli Brinckerhoff & Abady LLP
75 Rockefeller Plaza, 20th Floor
New York, New York 10019
By: Matthew D. Brinckerhoff, Esq.
Wolf Haldenstein Adler Freeman & Herz, LLP
270 Madison Avenue
New York 10016
By:  Jeffrey G. Smith, Esq.
For the Defendants:
Lorna B. Goodman
Nassau County Attorney
One West Street
Mineola, New York 11501
By: Dennis J. Saffran, Esq.
Liora Ben-Sorek, Esq.

HURLEY, Senior District Judge:
Following remand by the Second Circuit, see In re Nassau County Strip Search Cases, 
461 F.3d 219 (2d Cir. 2006), this Court, by Order dated January 16, 2007, (1) certified for
liability purposes a class consisting of “all persons arrested for misdemeanors or non-criminal
offenses in Nassau County who thereafter were strip searched at the Nassau County Correctional
Center pursuant to defendants’ blanket policy, practice and custom which required that all
arrestees be strip-searched upon admission to the facility, from May 10,1996 until and including
June 1, 1999"; (2) appointed counsel for the class; and (3) granted summary judgment on liability
for all strip searches upon admission to the facility against defendants Joseph Jablonsky and the
County of Nassau and in favor of the certified class and each and every member thereof. 
Presently before the Court is Plaintiffs’ application to certify the class as to Plaintiffs’ entire
claims, i.e., to extend class certification to include damages.  Defendants oppose the application
on the grounds that the predominance test for class certification cannot be met because of the
“highly variable and individualized damages” of the class members.  As set forth in detail below,
the Court finds that extending class certification to the entire claim is appropriate because
questions common to class members predominate over any questions affecting only individual
members and a class action is superior to other available methods for adjudicating this
controversy.  Accordingly, the application is granted.
Background
The background of this action is set forth in the prior decisions of this Court as well as
the Second Circuit’s decision directing this Court to certify a class on liability and to consider 
2

anew whether to certify a class as to damages as well.  Familiarity with those decisions is
presumed.   It suffices to note that these consolidated actions seek damages due to the blanket
policy of the Nassau County Correction Center (“NCCC”) of strip searching newly admitted,
misdemeanor detainees.   Said policy was declared to violate clearly established Fourth
Amendment law in Shain v. Ellison, 53 F. Supp. 2d 564 (E.D.N.Y. 1999), aff’d in part,
remanded in part, 273 F.3d 56 (2d Cir. 2001).
Discussion
I.  Class Certification Generally
Class action certification is governed by Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23.  Class
certification may be granted only if the court “is satisfied after a ‘rigorous analysis’ that the
prerequisites of Rule 23 have been satisfied.”  In re Initial Public Offering Sec. Litig., 471 F.3d
24, 32 (2d Cir. 2006), clarified on denial of rehear’g, 483 F.3d 70 (2d Cir. 2007) (quoting Gen.
Tel. Co. of Southwest v. Falcon, 457 U.S. 147, 161 (1982)).  The following standard governs
class certification motions in the Second Circuit:
(1) a district judge may certify a class only after making
determinations that each of the Rule 23 requirements has been met;
(2) such determinations can be made only if the judge resolves
factual disputes relevant to each Rule 23 requirement and finds that
whatever underlying facts are relevant to a particular Rule 23
requirement have been established and is persuaded to rule, based
on the relevant facts and the applicable legal standard, that the
requirement is met; (3) the obligation to make such determinations
is not lessened by overlap between a Rule 23 requirement and a
merits issue, even a merits issue that is identical with a Rule 23
requirement; (4) in making such determinations, a district judge
should not assess any aspect of the merits unrelated to a Rule 23
requirement; and (5) a district judge has ample discretion to
3

circumscribe both the extent of discovery concerning Rule 23
requirements and the extent of a hearing to determine whether such
requirements are met in order to assure that a class certification
motion does not become a pretext for a partial trial of the merits.
Id.  
A moving party must satisfy all four prerequisites to certification contained in Rule 23(a). 
Additionally, the class must be maintainable as defined in Rule 23(b).  This Court has already
found that Rule 23(a)’s requirements of numerosity, commonality, typicality and adequacy have
been met in this case. 
Turning then to Rule 23(b), it is subsection 3 on which these Plaintiffs rely.  Under Rule
23(b)(3), a class action may be maintained if: 
(3) the court finds that the questions of law or fact common to the
members of the class predominate over any questions affecting only individual
members, and that a class action is superior to other available methods for the fair
and efficient adjudication of the controversy. . . .
Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b)(3).
For a class to be certified under Rule 23(b)(3), Plaintiffs must demonstrate both (1) that
the questions of law or fact common to the members of the class predominate over any questions
affecting only individual members; and (2) that a class action is superior to other available
methods for the fair and efficient adjudication of the controversy.
II.  The Requirements of Rule 23(b)(3) Have Been Met
A.   Rule 23(b)(3) Generally
The predominance and superiority requirements of Rule 23(b)(3) “ensure that the class
will be certified only when it would ‘achieve economies of time, effort and expenses and
promote . . . uniformity of decision as to persons similarly situated, without sacrificing 
4

procedural fairness or bringing about other undesirable results.’”  Cordes & Co. Fin. Servs. Inc.
v. A.G. Edwards & Sons, Inc., 502 F.3d 91, 104 (2d Cir. 2007) (quoting Amchem Prods. Inc. v.
Windsor, 521 U.S. 591, 615 (1997) (ellipses in original)). 
“To meet the predominance requirement of Rule 23(b)(3), a plaintiff must establish that
the issues in the class action that are subject to generalized proof, and thus applicable to the class
as a whole . . . predominate over those issues that are subject only to individualized proof.”  In re
Visa Check/MasterMoney Antitrust Litig., 280 F.3d 124, 136 (2d Cir. 2001) (quotation marks and
citation omitted).  The predominance inquiry “tests whether proposed classes are sufficiently
cohesive to warrant adjudication by representation,” Moore v. PaineWebber, Inc., 306 F.3d 1247,
1252 (2d Cir. 2002), and “all factual or legal issues that are common to the class inform the
analysis.”  Nassau County Strip Search Cases, 461 F.3d at 227.  “[A]n issue is common to the
class when it is susceptible to generalized, class-wide proof.”  Id.   “The Rule ‘encompasses
those cases in which a class action would achieve economies of time, effort, and expense, and
promote uniformity of decision as to persons similarly situated, without sacrificing procedural
fairness or bringing about other undesirable results.’”  Id. (quoting Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b)(3) adv.
comm. n. to 1966 amend.). 
B.  The Contention of the Parties   
In their initial submission following remand by the Second Circuit, Plaintiffs argued that
the class certification should include damages so that damages can de determined on a class wide
basis.  Plaintiffs suggested several “models” whereby damages could be determined class wide.  
Two of the models were settlement models previously rejected by this Court.  Another model 
5

was one that was discontinued when it proved too cumbersome, leading to decertification of the
class before damages were determined.  See Lowery v. Circuit City Stores, Inc., 158 F.3d 742,
758 (4th Cir. 1998).  The final model was one that the appellate court conceded was
“unorthodox” and raised serious due process concerns but was justified by the extraordinarily
unusual nature of the case.  See Hilao v. Estate of Marcos, 103 F.3d 767, 782-87 (9th Cir. 1996).  
  In response to queries by this Court, Plaintiffs have refined their position.  Plaintiffs
maintain that the injury to human dignity is common to the class in its scope, nature, cause and
harm suffered.  They assert that “[t]he amount recoverable for this injury does not depend on the
characteristics of each individual; rather the injury to human dignity suffered by each plaintiff,
and resulting right to compensatory damages for such injury, redound to each plaintiff in the
same manner because of his or her humanity.”  Pls.’ Mem. in Further Supp. of Cert. of a
Damages Class Pursuant to Court’s May 30, 2007 Order (“Pls.’ Supp. Mem.”) at 2.   It is further
argued that the injury to human dignity is inextricably intertwined in the nature of the unlawful
act at issue - the strip search - and therefore certain damages can be presumed such that there are
sufficient commonalities as to damages to support a finding of predominance.  Id.1   Defendants
respond that presumed or general damages are granted only in limited, individual situations and
the award of presumed or general damages in a class action is unprecedented and was, in fact,
implicitly rejected by the Second Circuit in the context of a strip search in Shain v. Ellison, 273
1  With respect to those class members that may have suffered special damages, Plaintiffs
are unwilling to concede at this point that such damages may not be common.  They maintain the
Court should find predominance in the damages for human dignity issue and await discovery
before determining how to handle any claims of special damages. 
6

F.3d 56, 67 (2d Cir. 2001).  Defs.’ Supp. Mem. Pursuant to Court’s May 30, 2007 Order in Opp.
to Cert. of a Damages Class (“Defs.’ Supp. Mem.”) at 2. 
C.  The Issue of General Damages for Dignity Harm Predominates
In Carey v. Piphus, 435 U.S. 247 (1978) and Memphis Community Sch. Dist. v. Stachura,
477 U.S. 299 (1986), the Supreme Court established the basic parameters for awarding
compensatory damages in Section 1983 actions.  The Court in Carey held, in a case involving
procedural due process, that it is inappropriate to permit “presumed damages.”  Rather, the
purpose of damages awards in § 1983 actions is to compensate for actual injury.  In the absence
of proof of actual injury, students wrongfully suspended from school in violation of procedural
due process were entitled only to nominal damages and not unspecified damages to compensate
them for injury inherent in the nature of the wrong.  435 U.S. at 252-55.  In Memphis
Community, the Court reiterated that when “§ 1983 plaintiffs seek damages for violations of
constitutional rights, the level of damages is ordinarily determined according to principles
derived from the common law of torts.”  477 U.S. at 306.    To that end, “damages based on the
abstract ‘value’ or ‘importance’ of constitutional rights are not a permissible element of
compensatory damages in [§ 1983] cases” and “nominal damages, and not damages based on
some undefinable ‘value’ of infringed rights, are the appropriate means of vindicating rights
whose deprivation has not caused actual, provable injury.”  Id. at 308 & n.11, 310.  Whether the
constitutional basis for § 1983 liability is substantive or procedural, “damages must always be
designed to compensate for the constitutional deprivation.”  Id. at 309.   
The Court in Memphis Community did, however, distinguish between damages based on
the value of the constitutional right violated and presumed damages.  The Court stated: “When a
7

plaintiff seeks compensation for an injury that is likely to have occurred but difficult to establish,
some form of presumed damages may possibly be appropriate. . . . In those circumstances
presumed damages may roughly approximate the harm that the plaintiff suffered and thereby
compensate for harms that may be impossible to measure.”  Id. at 311 (citations omitted).    
Here, the Plaintiffs are not claiming damages based on the value of their Fourth
Amendment right to be free from unreasonable searches and seizures.   Such a claim is
foreclosed by Carey and Memphis Community.  Plaintiffs maintain that once an illegal strip
search is shown to have taken place, a fortiori there is injury to human dignity.  This position
finds support in the Second Circuit’s decision in Kerman v. City of New York, 374 F.3d 93 (2d
Cir. 2004). 
In Kerman, a jury found that the plaintiff’s fourth amendment rights were violated by his
unjustified detention in a psychiatric hospital overnight but awarded him only nominal damages
of one dollar.  The trial court denied the motion of the plaintiff, Kerman, for a new trial as to
damages on his fourth amendment claims and Kerman appealed.  The Second Circuit reversed,
holding that while Kerman was not entitled to a new trial with respect to damages for his claimed
physical pain, mental suffering and medical expenses, he should have been granted a new trial
with respect to damages for his loss of liberty.  Id. at 122.  
The Second Circuit began its damages discussion by noting that a plaintiff is not
automatically entitled to a substantial damages award because he has been deprived of a
constitutional right.  For example, “when a jury has found that the plaintiff proved a defendant
used excessive force against him in violation of his rights under the Fourth or Fifth Amendment,
a verdict that the plaintiff is not entitled to compensatory damages is not necessarily
8

impermissible.  A jury could reasonably find that only nominal damages are appropriate where
for example, a plaintiff’s testimony as to his injuries lacks objective support or credibility, or
where both justified force and unjustified force were used, either of which could have caused his
injuries . . . .”  Id.  at 123.   Applying these principles to the case before it, the Kerman court
concluded that the jury was not required to credit the testimony regarding Kerman’s mental
suffering and psychological injuries and therefore he was not entitled as a matter of law to
compensatory damages for his claims of physical pain, medical expenses, emotional suffering
and psychological injuries. Id. at 124.  
The Court then turned to Kerman’s damages claim for his loss of liberty and
distinguished it from his other damages claims.  “In contrast, where the jury has found a
constitutional violation and there is no genuine dispute that the violation resulted in some injury
to the plaintiff, the plaintiff is entitled to an award of compensatory damages as a matter of law.” 
Id.  The Court noted that in Raysor v. Port Authority, 768 F.2d 34, 38-39 (2d Cir. 1985) “where
the plaintiff was indisputably deprived of his liberty, and the conduct of the defendant
responsible for the deprivation was found to be unlawful, [it has] held that the plaintiff is entitled
to compensatory, not merely nominal, damages.”  The Court continued:
Raysor is consistent with traditional common-law principles
governing entitlement to damages for the tort of false
imprisonment.  That tort ‘is complete with even a brief restraint of
the plaintiff’s freedom; it is not necessary that any damages result
from it other than the confinement itself. . . . The compensatory
damages that may be awarded for false imprisonment fall into two
categories: general damages and special damages. . . . General
damage is a harm of a sort inseparable from the unlawful restraint.
. . . For false imprisonment, upon pleading and proving merely the
unlawful interference with his liberty, the plaintiff is entitled to
general damages for loss of time and humiliation or mental
9

suffering. . . . Items of special damage [, on the other hand,]
commonly include physical discomfort, shock or injury to health,
loss of employment and injury to the plaintiff’s reputation or credit
and must be specifically pleaded and proven. . . . In contrast
general damage need not be specifically proved - it may be inferred
from the circumstances of the arrest or imprisonment and would
include at least the value of the time lost by the plaintiff during the
period of detention.
374 F.3d at 125 (internal quotations and citations omitted).  Because the jury was not instructed
that if they found the defendant had acted without probable cause Kerman was entitled to
compensatory damages for his loss of liberty, a new trial was necessary.   Id. at 129.  Accord
Gardner v. Federated Dept. Stores, Inc., 907 F.2d 1348 (2d Cir.1990) (upholding separate
damages awards for (1) general damages for deprivation of liberty, redressing the denial of free
movement and the violation done to the plaintiff’s dignity as a result of the unlawful detention,
and (2) special damages for pain and suffering from the resultant anxiety disorder). 
Here, it cannot be disputed that the violation at issue  - the strip search - resulted in some
injury to the class members.  As Plaintiffs aptly state:
The language used in cases to describe unlawful strip
searches captures the intuitive understanding of the harm
necessarily caused by such searches.  The intrusion caused by a
strip search is so great that objection to it is “instinctive.”  See Bell
v. Wolfish, 411 U.S. 520, 528 (1979) (strip-search with visual
inspection is the practice that “instinctively” gives “the most
pause”).  Strip-searches have been variously characterized as “a
serious impairment of privacy” and a “serious intrusion.” N.G. v.
Connecticut, 382 F.3d 225, 234 (2d Cir. 2004); “uniquely invasive
and upsetting,” id. at 239 (Sotomayor, J., dissenting); and
“demeaning,” “dehumanizing” and “terrifying,” MaryBeth G. v.
City of Chicago, 723 F.2d 1263, 1272 (7th Cir. 1983).  See Weber
v. Dell, 804 F.2d 796, 802 (2d Cir. 1986) (describing strip/body
cavity searches as “so intrusive and demeaning”); Doe v. Renfrow,
631 F.2d 91, 93 (7th Cir. 1980) (per curiam) (unlawful strip search
violated “any known principle of human decency” and “exceed[ed]
10

the ‘bounds of reason’ by two and a half country miles”). 
. . .  In Tinetti v. Wittke, 479 F. Supp. 486, 489 (E.D. Wisc.
1979), the district court observed that as to visual strip search
“[w]hile the total time involved in a strip search is minimal, the
humiliation and embarrassment experienced by the offenders are
much more lasting,” and described a strip search as being “an
intrusion on one’s personal dignity,” id. at 490.  Notably, most of
these descriptions of the violative quality of unlawful strip searches
were offered without specific references to the plaintiffs’ testimony
about their experiences; rather, the courts spoke to the common
nature of the harm caused by strip searches.
Pls.’ Supp. Mem at 8-9.  At the very least, class members are entitled to general damages.
Defendants maintain that the Second Circuit’s decision in Shain v. Ellison, 273 F.3d 56,
approving the award of nominal damages,  is an implicit rejection of the argument that the victim
of an unlawful strip search is entitled to general damages for injury to human dignity.  The Court
disagrees.  There is no indication in Shain that the parties raised, or that the Second Circuit
considered, whether the plaintiff was entitled to general damages for the unlawful strip search. 
Rather, the question was whether that plaintiff was entitled to special damages and as to that
question the Court found that the evidence was insufficient and therefore a nominal damage
award was appropriate.  Id. at 67.  Shain does not bar general damages for unlawful strip
searches.  
Nor is the Court persuaded by Defendants’ argument that even if general damages are
awardable in a strip search case there is no reason to believe that the rule would be extended to
class actions.  The Second Circuit has recognized, for example, that class-wide rather than
individual assessments of monetary relief may sometimes be appropriate in class discrimination
cases.  See Robinson v. Metro-North, 267 F.3d 147, 161 n. 6 (2d Cir. 2001).  See also Berger v.
Iron Workers Reinforced Rodmen, Local 201, 170 F.3d 1111, 1138 (D.C. Cir. 1999) (holding
11

that it was appropriate to presume that as a result of race discrimination those class members who
were experienced rodmen suffered emotional distress by having to subject themselves to an
unnecessary training program for up to two years before being permitted to take union entrance
exam and therefore damages award was supported and appropriate).  Moreover, “[p]roof of
aggregate monetary relief for [a] class is feasible and reasonable under various circumstance.”  3
Newburg on Class Actions § 10:2.  As the authors of one noted treatise have stated: “In situations
when aggregate proof of damages is sought to be proved on behalf of a class, no special or
unique rules of evidence are involved; nor are any special substantive principles invoked; nor is
defendant’s monetary liability increased at all from what it would be if all class members
individually proved their monetary claims.  Courts have approved various methods of discovery
and determining damages in class actions on the basis of classwide, rather than individualized
proof of damages and the use of statistics and representative samples are one such method.”  Id.  
Finally, the Second Circuit has noted that those cases in which plaintiffs are “aggrieved by a
single policy of the defendants” and there is a “strong commonality of the violation and the
harm” are “precisely the type of situation[s] for which the class action device is suited.”  In re
Visa Check, 280 F.3d at 146.    Here, class members were aggrieved by a single, admittedly
unlawful policy and there is a strong commonality between the strip search violation and the
harm.  There is no reason that a jury in this case, hearing the procedures used by Defendants for
strip searches together with the testimony of a number of class members as to the circumstance of
actual searches, could not determine an amount of general damages awardable to each member of
the class.  Concededly, care would have to be taken to ensure that the amount awarded for
general damages excludes all elements of special damages that individual class member might
12

then pursue.  But the task, albeit difficult, is doable.  
In sum, the Court determines that the issue of general damages is predominate.
D.  The Requirement of Superiority Has Been Met
Rule 23(b)(3) requires a court to consider whether a class action is superior to other
methods of adjudication.  To that end the court should examine “the interest of members of the
class in individually controlling the prosecution or defense of separate actions;” “the extent and
nature of any litigation concerning the controversy already commenced by or against members of
the class;” “the desirability or undesirability of concentrating the litigation of the claims in the
particular forum;” and “the difficulties likely to be encountered in the management of the class.” 
Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b)(3).  All these factors favor certification in this case.
Given that liability is established and the issue of general damages predominates,
concentrating the litigation in one forum will simplify and streamline the litigation process. As a
practicable matter, neither joinder nor intervention is a realistic alternative.  It would appear that
members of the class have little interest in individually controlling separate actions as the Court
has not been advised by the parties that any individual suits have been filed despite the amount of
time that has passed since this action was commenced.  The Court finds that Plaintiff have
satisfied the superiority requirement. 
Conclusion
For the reasons set forth herein, Plaintiffs’ motion to extend class certification to include
damages is hereby granted.  It should be noted that Plaintiffs are not asking this Court to select a
particular damages model or to certify any subclasses for special damages as to do so would be
“premature.”   Thus, the Court has neither selected nor foreclosed any particular damages model;
13

nor has it gone beyond determining that the predominancy of general damages warrants
extending class certification from solely liability to liability and damages. 
Plaintiffs shall submit a proposed order on notice within ten (10) days of the date hereof. 
The parties shall appear for a conference on May 9, 2008 at 2:00 p.m.
SO ORDERED.
Dated: Central Islip, New York
March 27, 2008
/s/____________________
Denis R. Hurley
Senior District Judge
14
